entry.et: Middle English, from Old English hliehhan; akin to Old High German lachēn to laugh

def.dt: :to show emotion (as mirth, joy, or scorn) with a chuckle or explosive vocal sound
:to find amusement or pleasure in something laughed at his own clumsiness
:to become amused or derisive a very skeptical public laughed at our early efforts Graenum Berger
:to produce the sound or appearance of laughter a laughing brook
:to be of a kind that inspires joy
:to influence or move by laughter laughed the bad singer off the stage
:diversion sport play baseball just for laughs
:to minimize by treating as amusingly or absurdly trivial
:recorded laughter that accompanies dialogue or action (as of a television program)
:the satisfaction of ultimate triumph or success especially after being scorned or regarded as a failure he got the last laugh on his early critics
